text: hello and welcome to the AWS cost
optimization Series in this episode you
will learn about pricing models and
we're going to take a quick tour of the
AWS pricing calculator
[Music]
so when you move to AWS one of the main
advantages is that you can move from a
cake packs to an Opex model not only
this helps you simplify your costs but
also you can completely reduce or
eliminate your upfront costs depending
on your preference on top of that when
you come to AWS you only pay for what
you use so not only you don't need to
worry about depreciating assets but also
you can scale your systems up and down
at any given time and we do have many
different Services catering for many
different needs and each one of those
have their own pricing model so it's
very important for you to understand the
cost model of each service that you want
to use now how do you do that well there
are two ways one you can check the
pricing page every service has their own
pricing page which gives you a detailed
breakdown of all the cost dimensions and
options that it offers now that can get
a bit difficult as you start using more
AWS services and start widening your AWS
at adoption so we have created a very
Nifty tool that tracks all the pricing
models behind the scenes for you of
every service and allows you to create
estimates and play around with all those
options and figures to really adjust the
cost for your solution and that is the
AWS pricing calculator so let's have a
quick look at it here I am on the main
AWS website you can navigate to this by
going to aws.amazon.com and there is a
search bar so we're going to click on
the search bar I'm going to type pricing
and uh that's enough to get me a match
so I'm going to click on AWS pricing
calculator
and here is where we can create an
estimate by clicking on this button so
I'm going to click on create estimate
and the first thing we're going to
notice is that there is a search
interface here and very importantly you
want to pick the right location type and
the right region when you find services
and that is because
pricing will differ depending on the
region so it's very important for you to
pick the right one in this case I
already got Ireland selected and that's
the one I wanted so I'm going to keep it
and then I'm going to go to find service
and I'm going to type ec2 so it's going
to give me the search results here
Amazon ec2 I can click on the product
page link to go to that project page
that I just mentioned or I can click on
configure when I click on configure
something magical happens it gives me
defaults based on the pricing model of
that ec2 service and then all you need
to do is tweak it to my needs so in this
case it has defaulted to a Linux service
server and it has defaulted to four vcp
use and 16 gigabytes of memory now that
has matched to the lowest cost ec2
instance and that is the T4 g.x large I
don't need to know what that instance is
it tells me that that is the best one
for my needs and then down here it
already gives me a little price of where
my estimate is at
um now let's update this and I'm going
to change the vcpu from four to one and
the memory to four and as you can see
here it has updated the recommendation
of the lowest cost ec2 instance to t4g
dot medium and it has updated the cost
here so I'm Gonna Save and enter service
to my estimate and here at the bottom
you will see that my estimate now has a
projection of monthly costs and a
projection for my yearly cost which is
the amalgamation of everything that I've
added to my estimate if I go on view
summary I can see just that and I can
see all the figures or the breakdowns I
can continue to add Services I can add
AWS support tiers and I can share with
colleagues by clicking here and copy the
public link which allows me to share
with anyone now lastly you can export
this to CSV or PDF so for example if you
want to print it allowing to take this
estimate to all those very important
meetings about costs thank you very much
I hope you have learned something new
today keep on learning keep on building
on abs
